docs.lead_paragraph: “Engaging in a discussion about end-of-life issues does not have to be a dark, depressing matter. Many people are willing to spend a Saturday learning CPR, but their time would be better spent drawing up an advance directive.”.

headline.main: Taking the Time to Teach, and Learn, About Advance Directives
headline.print_headline: Taking the Time to Teach, and Learn, About Advance Directives

docs.snippet: “Engaging in a discussion about end-of-life issues does not have to be a dark, depressing matter. Many people are willing to spend a Saturday learning CPR, but their time would be better spent drawing up an advance directive.”.

docs.lead_paragraph: When I ask people whether and how they have made preparations for the ends of their lives, the most frequent response is, ''Well, I have a living will.'' But chances are they are unaware of the serious limitations inherent in such a document and how it is likely to be interpreted by medical personnel should a life-threatening crisis arise. A living will is an advance directive, a document that states your wishes about how you should be cared for at the end of your life. It is meant to be activated when you are unable to say what you do or do not want to be done medically -- if, for example, you are in a terminal condition, your heart and breathing cease, you are in a persistent vegetative state because of severe brain damage or you are too demented to understand the situation.

headline.main: Medical Due Diligence: A Living Will Should Spell Out the Specifics

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses details that should be included in living will and things to consider in establishing health care proxy; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Walda Lyons's life has been marked by hardship, but it is not obvious from her demeanor. She survived polio as a child and cancer as an adult and at 62 is determined to resume working for a living. Dressed in a neat two-piece outfit, as if she were preparing for a job interview, she presented a certain professional air. But after decades in white-collar jobs, Ms. Lyons has been unemployed since she was laid off in April 2002 by her employer, which then went out of business.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Regaining Independence After Polio and Cancer

docs.abstract: Walda Lyons receives help with utility bill from Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, beneficiary agency of New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)
